review.title: Scheduling Bipartite Tournaments to Minimize Total Travel Distance
review.abstract: In many professional sports leagues, teams from opposing leagues/conferences compete against one another, playing inter-league games. This is an example of a bipartite tournament. In this paper, we consider the problem of reducing the total travel distance of bipartite tournaments, by analyzing inter-league scheduling from the perspective of discrete optimization. This research has natural applications to sports scheduling, especially for leagues such as the National Basketball Association (NBA) where teams must travel long distances across North America to play all their games, thus consuming much time, money, and greenhouse gas emissions. We introduce the Bipartite Traveling Tournament Problem (BTTP), the inter-league variant of the well-studied Traveling Tournament Problem. We prove that the 2n-team BTTP is NP-complete, but for small values of n, a distance-optimal inter-league schedule can be generated from an algorithm based on minimum-weight 4-cycle-covers. We apply our theoretical results to the 12-team Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) league in Japan, producing a provably-optimal schedule requiring 42950 kilometres of total team travel, a 16% reduction compared to the actual distance traveled by these teams during the 2010 NPB season. We also develop a nearly-optimal inter-league tournament for the 30-team NBA league, just 3.8% higher than the trivial theoretical lower bound.

sections.text: We introduce the Bipartite Traveling Tournament Problem (BTTP), the cross-league variant of the well-researched Traveling Tournament Problem. We prove that the 2n team BTTP is NP-complete, but at low values of n an algorithm based on 4-cycle covers with minimal weight can generate a distance-optimized interleague schedule. We apply our theoretical results to the 12-member Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) league in Japan, resulting in a demonstrably optimal schedule requiring 42950 kilometers of total itinerary, a 16% reduction compared to the actual distance traveled by these teams during the 2010 NPB season. We also develop a near-optimal interleague tournament for the 30-team NBA league that is only 3.8% above the trivial theoretical lower limit.

sections.heading: 4. Japanese Baseball
sections.text: Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) is Japan's largest professional sports league with two games in the Pacific League. In the NPB, teams are divided into two six-team leagues, with each team playing 120 intraleague- and 24 inter-league games during the regular season. Intra-league issues were recently analyzed by the authors (Hoshino & Kawarabayashi, 2011c), with a multiround generalization of the league based on Dijkstra's shortest-distance algorithm to reduce total travel distances by over 60,000 kilometers (a 25% reduction) compared to the 2010 NPB intra-league schedule (Hoshino & Kawarabayashi, 2011d). Given that Japan is a small island country, a 60,000-kilometer reduction represents a significant sum, with the six teams in the Pacific League playing four games against all six teams in the NPB.

sections.heading: 5. American Basketball
sections.text: The National Basketball Association (NBA) is one of the most lucrative sports leagues in the world, with over $4 billion in annual revenue and an average franchise value of $400 million. So there are 15 teams in the Western Conference and 15 teams in the Eastern Conference. Each NBA team plays 82 regular season games, of which 30 are within the NBA (with one home game and one away game against each of the 15 teams from the other conference). In this theoretical problem, we assume that all interleague games take place in the regular season, as is currently done in the Japanese NPB. We will also enforce all restrictions of the BTTP, including no team that has a home record or a road trip of more than 3 games.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced the two-tier equestrian tournament problem and applied it to two professional sports leagues in Japan and North America that have a uniform weight distribution of the two tournaments in Japan and North America, illustrating the richness and complexity of the two-tier tournament planning. In Section 4, we introduced two heuristics that allowed us to solve BTTP for the n = 6 NPBs. While Proposition 2 only applies to certain 12-team configurations that fulfill a specific geometric property, we point out that Proposition 1 is a general technique that can be applied to other planning problems. Our "pre-spread reduction" method breaks down a complex problem into a large number of scenarios and uses each scenario as a global constraint to reduce the search space. We are confident that Proposition 1 can be applied to more complicated problems in sports planning. In Section 5, we have determined an algorithm that produces a solution approaching BTTP = the NBA 15.
